required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Effects of Respiratory Training on Respiratory and Functional Performance in Patients With Stroke
clinical_study.official_title: Effects of Respiratory Training on Respiratory and Functional Performance in Patients With Stroke

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of the research is to investigate the effects of respiratory training on respiratory and functional performance in patients with stroke.

detailed_description.textblock: Stroke ranks third in the global cause of death, behind cancer and coronary heart disease. Stroke is also the third largest cause of death in Taiwan in 2014. Stroke patients in the course of exercise are in addition to muscle weakness and reduced endurance, but usually also accompanied by respiratory damage. From past studies have shown that stroke patients whose respiratory function has significant change, such as decreased respiratory muscle strength, reduced respiratory movement of the affected hemithorax, declined in maximum breathing pressure and decreased amplitude of diaphragmatic movements on the paralyzed side. But whether respiratory training can improve respiratory and functional performance of stroke patients, because of the limited research results could not be confirmed.

primary_outcome.time_frame: change from baseline diaphragm thickness at 12, 16, 24, 36 weeks.
primary_outcome.description: In this study, the mid axillary lines between ribs 8 and 9 on both sides will be checked in a standing posture, then the chest wall is perpendicularly illuminated by a curved array 2-5 MHz transducer (Siemens Sololine G40) in an upright sitting position to observe the region between rib 8 and rib 9 in 2D images. The diaphragm thickness is measured as the distance between two parallel lines that appear bright in the middle of the pleura and in the middle peritoneum.

primary_outcome.time_frame: change from baseline incidence of pneumonia at 12, 16, 24, 36 weeks.
primary_outcome.description: This study will observe the incidence of pneumonia of two groups in the 36-week research course.

primary_outcome.time_frame: change from baseline Brunnstrom's stages at 12, 16, 24, 36 weeks.
primary_outcome.description: The six sequential stages of motor recovery through which the hemiplegic upper and lower extremities progress used as a method for assessing recovery.

primary_outcome.measure: Stroke Rehabilitation Assessment of Movement scale; STREAM.
primary_outcome.time_frame: change from baseline STREAM scores at 12, 16, 24, 36 weeks.
primary_outcome.description: The STREAM scale is used to evaluate the recovery of voluntary movement and basic mobility following stroke. The scale consists of 30 items or test movements that are equally distributed among 3 subscales: upper-limb movements, lower-limb movements, and basic mobility items.

primary_outcome.measure: Stroke-Specific Quality of Life scale; SS-QOL.
primary_outcome.time_frame: change from baseline SS-QOL scores at 12, 16, 24, 36 weeks.
primary_outcome.description: The SS-QOL scale is a patient-centered outcome measure intended to provide an assessment of health-related quality of life specific to patients with stroke. It consists of twelve commonly affected domains (energy, family roles, language, mobility, mood, personality, self-care, social roles, thinking, upper extremity functioning, vision, and work/productivity) and 49 items.

primary_outcome.time_frame: change from baseline SIS 3.0 scores at 12, 16, 24, 36 weeks.
primary_outcome.description: The SIS 3.0 is a stroke-specific, self-report, health status measure. The scale includes 59 items and assesses 8 domains. It was designed to assess multidimensional stroke outcomes, including strength, hand function, activities of daily living/instrumental activities of daily living (ADL/IADL), mobility, communication, emotion, memory and thinking, and participation.

primary_outcome.time_frame: change from baseline Twelve-Minute Walk Test scores at 12, 16, 24, 36 weeks.
primary_outcome.description: The distance (in meters) that a subject can walk within twelve minutes is evaluated.

primary_outcome.time_frame: change from baseline FVC at 12, 16, 24, 36 weeks.
primary_outcome.description: Resting spirometry of FVC will be performed on a spirometer.

primary_outcome.time_frame: change from baseline VC at 12, 16, 24, 36 weeks.
primary_outcome.description: Resting spirometry of VC will be performed on a spirometer.

primary_outcome.measure: Forced Expiratory Volume at 1 second (FEV1) in liters.
primary_outcome.time_frame: change from baseline FEV1 at 12, 16, 24, 36 weeks.
primary_outcome.description: Resting spirometry of FEV1 will be performed on a spirometer.

primary_outcome.time_frame: change from baseline FEV1/FVC ratio at 12, 16, 24, 36 weeks.
primary_outcome.description: Resting spirometry of FEV1/FVC ratio will be performed on a spirometer.

primary_outcome.measure: Forced Expiratory Flow rate 25-75% (FEF 25-75%) in liters per minute.
primary_outcome.time_frame: change from baseline FEF 25-75% at 12, 16, 24, 36 weeks.
primary_outcome.description: Resting spirometry of FEF 25-75% will be performed on a spirometer.

primary_outcome.measure: Peak Expiratory Flow Rate (PEFR) in liters per minute.
primary_outcome.time_frame: change from baseline PEFR at 12, 16, 24, 36 weeks.
primary_outcome.description: Resting spirometry of PEFR will be performed on a spirometer.

primary_outcome.measure: Maximum Inspiratory Pressure (PImax) in centimeters of water pressure (cmH2O).
primary_outcome.time_frame: change from baseline PImax at 12, 16, 24, 36 weeks.
primary_outcome.description: Resting spirometry of PImax will be performed on a spirometer.

primary_outcome.measure: Maximum Expiratory Pressures (PEmax) in centimeters of water pressure (cmH2O).
primary_outcome.time_frame: change from baseline PEmax at 12, 16, 24, 36 weeks.
primary_outcome.description: Resting spirometry of PEmax will be performed on a spirometer.

primary_outcome.measure: Maximum Voluntary Ventilation (MVV) in liters per minute.
primary_outcome.time_frame: change from baseline MVV at 12, 16, 24, 36 weeks.
primary_outcome.description: Resting spirometry of MVV will be performed on a spirometer.

arm_group.description: Besides traditional rehabilitation therapy, subjects also receive 12-week respiratory training.
Besides traditional rehabilitation therapy, subjects receive 12-week sham training unrelated to respiratory function.

intervention.description: range of motion (ROM) exercise, stretching exercise or positioning exercise.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- first episode of unilateral stroke.
- the definition of stroke was according to the World Health Organization (WHO) criteria (Hatano 1976), confirmed by computerized tomography (CT) or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI).
- older than 20 years.
- had maximum inspiratory pressure (MIP) values lower than 90% of those predicted and adjusted for age and sex.
- facial palsy, which could not prevent proper labial occlusion.
- ability to understand and follow simple verbal instructions.
- no receptive aphasia.
- not undergone thoracic or abdominal surgery.
Exclusion Criteria:
- unable to perform the tests.
- impaired level of consciousness and evidence of gross cognitive impairment.
- excluded patients with comorbidities of respiratory system disease (e.g. chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, asthma, cystic fibrosis), or other diseases leading to the impairment of respiratory muscle (e.g. myasthenia gravis).
